Graphical abstract The regenerated materials from spent automotive LIBs can be reused for battery production, achieving resource recycling and environmental protection effects. The recycling of spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) has aroused considerable interest among the general public, industry professionals, and academic researchers, driven by its environmental, resource recovery, and economic benefits, particularly for those used in new energy vehicles. However, recycling spent automotive LIBs for industrial production remains challenging due to technical feasibility, recycling efficiency, economic viability, and environmental sustainability. This review aims to systematically analyze the status of spent automotive LIBs recycling, and provide an overall review of the full-chain recycling processes for technical evaluation and selection. Firstly, it carefully describes the pre-treatment process, which includes discharging, disassembly, inspection, crushing, pyrolysis, and sieving of LIBs. Subsequently, it examines the principal technologies in extracting valuable metals, including pyro-metallurgy, hydro-metallurgy, microbial metallurgy, mechanical chemistry, and electrochemical deposition. A comprehensive analysis of the operation, mechanism, efficiency, and economics is provided, helping readers understand the technical advantages, disadvantages, and applicable scenarios of each process. Furthermore, it also considers novel environmentally-friendly processes, such as direct regeneration and direct synthesis, and analyzes their potential and limitations in the resource recycling field. Finally, differentiated comprehensive recycling strategies are proposed for typical spent automotive LIBs, aiming at providing effective guidance and recommendations for industrial investors and practitioners, and promoting sustainable development of the comprehensive recycling industry. Keywords New energy vehicle Lithium iron phosphate battery Ternary lithium-ion battery Echelon utilization Comprehensive recycling 1 Introduction Based on the “Carbon Peaking and Carbon Neutrality Goals” policy, the new energy automobile industry of China has developed rapidly. Exactly, China's new energy automobile production and sales ranked first in the world for ten consecutive years, accounting for more than 60% of the world's amount. In October 2020, the General Office of the State Council of China issued the “Development Plan for New Energy Vehicle Industry (2021–2035)”, which aimed further to promote the high-quality development of the new energy automobile industry and accelerate the construction of a strong automotive country. As shown in Table 1 , China's annual sales of new energy vehicles present a steady growth from 18,000 units in 2013 to 1,367,000 units in 2020. Since 2021, China's annual sales of new energy vehicles have experienced explosive growth, reaching 12,866,000 units in 2024. The rapid development of the new energy vehicle industry has greatly promoted the development of the related automotive LIBs recycling industry. As the main power source, LIBs have been regarded as the most critical component of new energy vehicles, accounting for 30% to 40% cost of the whole vehicle, which has a very high economic recycling value. The service life of automotive LIBs is up to 20 years. However, when the actual capacity of LIBs decreases to less than 80% of the initial capacity, they should be decommissioned and no longer be used in new energy vehicles [1]. Therefore, the life expectancy of automotive LIBs for new energy vehicles is generally 5–8 years, and the service life of automotive LIBs used in public services will be even shorter, with the battery life of electric buses generally being 5 years, and that of electric taxis generally being 2–4 years [2]. Spent automotive LIBs contain high-value metal elements, of which the average mass fractions of Li, Ni, Co, and Mn can be up to 2.0–5.0 wt%, 5.0–12.0 wt%, 5.0–20.0 wt%, and 7.0–10.0 wt% respectively [3], which is much higher than that of metal content in mineral extraction [4]. Given the inferior quality of China's Li, Ni, and Co ores, there is a considerable reliance on imports from abroad. Consequently, the recycling of spent automotive LIBs assumes great significance at the national level. As reported by EVTank in Mar. 2024, China’s 2023 actual end-of-life (EOL) volume of automotive LIBs is 623,000 tonnes, with the actual recycling capacity only being 16.4%. As also estimated by EVTank, China’s annual recycling capacity of spent automotive LIBs will reach 10,242,000 tonnes by 2028, with an anticipated market value to exceed 300 billion yuan. Influenced by the double stimulation of national policy and economic interests, many enterprises, manufacturers, universities, and research institutes, have chosen to join this rapidly growing field. Comprehensive recycling of spent automotive LIBs can not only promote the recycling of Li, Ni, Co, and other valuable metal resources, but also lead to economic growth, reduce the potential threat of heavy metals to human health and the ecological environment, providing multiple economic, environmental and social benefits [5]. Notably, the recycling industry for spent automotive LIBs is still in its infancy at the industrial level. There are significant challenges in ensuring the production scale, technical quality, and environmental compliance of these recycling operations, which is incompatible with the development needs of this rapidly expanding industry. Based on the current development of the comprehensive recycling industry for spent automotive LIBs, this work provides an overview of overall full-chain recycling processes and technologies from three aspects: technical characteristics, process routes, and applicable scenarios. In addition, comprehensive recycling strategies for typical spent automotive LIBs are proposed. The overall purpose of this study is to supply comprehensive insight into the recycling of spent automotive LIBs, and to provide scientific guidance for related technical, research, and managerial personnel, propelling the sustainable development of the LIBs recycling industry. 2 Overview of LIBs and full-chain industry 2.1 Overview of LIBs 2.1.1 LIBs categories LIBs can be broadly classified into four main categories: cylindrical batteries, prismatic batteries, pouch batteries, and coin batteries (Fig. 1 ). Among these, prismatic batteries have emerged as the dominant choice in the new energy automobile market. As reported by the CHNCI in Apr. 2024, the total loaded capacity of prismatic batteries in 2023 reached 347.0 GWh, representing a market share of 89.5%. In comparison, pouch and cylindrical batteries accounted for only 7.4% and 3.1%, respectively. 2.1.2 LIBs constituents As shown in Fig. 2 , LIBs are comprised of a battery shell, cathode, anode, separator and electrolyte [7]. The cathode of LIBs comprises current-collector Al foil, positive electrode active material, binder, and conductive agent. The anode of LIBs includes current-collector Cu foil, a negative electrode active material, a binder, and a conductive agent. The separator is primarily composed of polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), and other composite separators [8,9]. The electrolyte is primarily constituted of solute, solvent, and additives. The predominant component of solute is lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6), while the solvent is primarily composed of ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), diethyl carbonate (DEC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC), and ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), which is formulated according to a specific ratio [10,11]. The cathode active material is primarily comprised of lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4), ternary materials (LiCo x Ni y Mn1− x − y O2), lithium cobaltate (LiCoO2), lithium manganate (LiMn2O4) and lithium nickelate (LiNiO2), etc. [12]. The main component of the binder is primarily composed of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [13]. The conductive agent is predominantly comprised of conventional conductive agents, including conductive carbon black, conductive graphite, and carbon fiber, as well as emerging conductive agents, such as carbon nanotubes and graphene [14]. 2.1.3 The LIBs used for new energy vehicles LIBs can be classified according to their cathode material, resulting in five distinct types: ternary lithium-ion batteries (T-LIBs), lithium iron phosphate (LFPs), lithium cobaltate batteries (LCOs), lithium manganate batteries (LMOs), and lithium nickelate batteries (LNOs) [16,17]. As indicated by the China Automotive Battery Industry Innovation Alliance “2023–2024 China Automotive Battery and Hydrogen Fuel Battery Industry Development Annual Report”, the two most dominant choices for new energy vehicles are T-LIBs and LFPs. The T-LIBs exhibit a higher energy density than LFPs. Meanwhile, they also present a higher risk for safety issues, including spontaneous combustion and subsequent explosion when exposed to the atmosphere. Historically, LIBs safety incidents have been predominantly associated with T-LIBs, largely due to the inherent challenges associated with their handling. In contrast, LFPs exhibit enhanced safety characteristics, as their energy density is comparatively lower. The initial generation of LFPs encountered technical challenges that limited their suitability for application into new energy vehicles. In recent years, the rapid development of battery technology has led to a notable increase in the energy density of LFPs. As a result, LFPs' benefits like low cost, high safety, and long lifespan are gaining more attention in the market. As illustrated in Fig. 3 , since 2021, LFPs have overtaken T-LIBs in market share, becoming the market leader. In 2024, the loaded capacity of LFPs reached 409.0 GWh, accounting for 74.6% of the total loaded amount. This represents a year-on-year increase of 56.7%. In comparison, the total loaded capacity of T-LIBs is 139.0 GWh, accounting for only 25.3% of the total loaded amount. This represents a year-on-year growth of 10.2%. Considering personnel safety and operating costs, LFPs have now become the predominant choice for commercial vehicles and are widely utilized in all models, including electric two-wheelers, electric three-wheelers, and electric cars. In contrast, T-LIBs are primarily employed in high-grade vehicles, as well as in passenger vehicles with high power and endurance requirements, such as sport utility vehicles (SUVs), and medium-sized and large vehicles. 2.2 Overview of automotive LIBs manufacturing industry In 2024, there are 55 enterprises in China engaged in the production of automotive batteries. As illustrated in Table 2 , the leading enterprise is CATL, with a market share of 45.08%, significantly ahead of its competitors. This is successively followed by BYD, CALB, GOTION, EVE, SVOLT, SUNWODA, REPT, ZENERGY and LGES, with the market share of 24.74%, 6.68%, 4.59%, 3.43%, 3.18%, 2.89%, 2.22%, 1.80% and 1.40%, respectively. The top 2, top 5 and top 10 battery enterprises accounted for 70.0%, 84.5%, and 96.0% of the total market-loaded volume, with a total of 381.0, 461.2, and 524.1 GWh, respectively. Each top-ranked enterprise possesses considerable technical prowess and has individual featured products. For instance, CATL and BYD specialize in T-LIBs and LFPs, the featured batteries of which are “Kirin Batteries” and “Blade Batteries”, respectively. 2.3 Overview of automotive LIBs comprehensive recycling industrial chain The comprehensive recycling industry for spent automotive LIBs is the core of the whole recycling industrial chain. It is primarily responsible for the resourceful utilization of spent automotive LIBs. The low entry threshold of the comprehensive recycling industry has resulted in the establishment of many recycling enterprises with miscellaneous types. Since 2018, the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) of China has published five successive lists of enterprises following the “Industry Specification Conditions for Comprehensive Utilization of Used Automotive Batteries for New Energy Vehicles” (Table 3 ). These lists, also known as the “white list”, comprise the ratified enterprises of the automotive LIBs recycling industry. To date, a total of 156 enterprises have been approved as white-listed enterprises, comprising 96 reusing enterprises and 60 recycling enterprises, of which only 12 enterprises have been deemed qualified for both reusing and recycling. However, there are approximately 120,000 enterprises engaged in the automotive LIBs recycling industry, indicating that most of these enterprises still exist in the form of small workshops. The annual processing capacity of the top enterprises exceeds 100,000 tonnes, with some reaching 10,000 tonnes. Overall, China's automotive LIBs recovery industry is undergoing rapid development and the current design capacity has greatly exceeded its theoretical recycling scale of spent automotive LIBs recovery, indicating a significant overcapacity phenomenon. The upstream of the spent automotive LIBs recycling industry is the recycling channel industry. Its primary function is to provide spent automotive LIBs and battery waste for the comprehensive recycling industry. At present, the spent automotive LIBs recycling industry has not yet established an official, unified recycling system. Meanwhile, the major LIBs recycling enterprises are vigorously competing for the market and the reality of LIBs recycling channels is characterized by a multiplicity of diverse and disparate entities, including battery factories, vehicle manufacturers, third-party operators, car wreckers, and insurance companies (Table 4 ). For formal comprehensive recycling enterprises, 50% of spent automotive LIBs originate from battery factories. To obtain a reliable and consistent supply of materials, recycling enterprises typically seek to establish long-term and mutually beneficial relationships with battery factories. Additionally, batteries discarded by vehicle manufacturers due to testing, use, recalls, and repairs are a major source for LIBs recycling, accounting for approximately 20% of the total spent automotive LIBs. Individual users have a diverse range of sources, limited supply, and maintenance challenges, often occupied by small market workshops. The downstream of the spent automotive LIBs recycling industry is the regenerated battery material recycling industry, which is primarily responsible for the reusing of secondary batteries and regenerated battery materials, including metals such as Ni, Co, Mn, Li, and other metals, plastics, graphite, electrolyte, etc. Following the white list, the downstream recycling enterprises can also be classified into two categories reusing enterprises and recycling enterprises. Among them, reusing enterprises are primarily involved in automotive grid enterprises, low-speed electric vehicle enterprises, and communication enterprises, including State Grid, Yutong Group, China Tower, etc. Recycling enterprises are primarily involved in battery material manufacturers, including Huayou Cobalt, Xiamen Tungsten, and Shanshan Corporation. 3 The comprehensive recycling processes of spent automotive LIBs The comprehensive recycling process of spent automotive LIBs can be divided into two principal segments: the pre-treatment process and the valuable metal recovery process. In general, when considering the recycling process in isolation, the conventional pre-treatment stage is the process of transforming the entire battery pack into its battery poles, cathode materials, and battery black powders. The subsequent stage of valuable metal recovery entails transforming the products into metal monomers or single metal compounds. The pre-treatment process can be subdivided into two principal categories: the reusing process and the recycling process. The valuable metal recovery section is similar to the conventional metallurgical process, with a relatively mature recycling system that mainly includes pyro-metallurgy and hydro-metallurgy processes, as well as other emerging processes, including microbial metallurgy, mechanical chemistry, electrochemical deposition, direct regeneration, and direct synthesis processes [18–20]. Nevertheless, there is a dearth of applications for these nascent techniques in the spent automotive LIBs recycling industry [21]. 3.1 Pre-treatment process As illustrated in Fig. 4 , the spent automotive LIBs pre-treatment process mainly consists of “discharging-dismantling-testing-reusing-crushing-pyrolysis-screening”, and it can be further divided into reusing, recycling, and fine dismantling routes according to different combinations. 3.1.1 Discharging process The initial step of the pre-treatment process is usually the discharging process [22]. The discharging process is an effective method of ensuring the safety of the subsequent dismantling work. Currently, the dismantling of spent automotive LIBs is still predominantly reliant on manual labor, with battery packs and modules often operating at a voltage higher than the human body's safety threshold (36 V). In certain instances, the voltage of the battery pack may exceed 350 V, thereby posing a considerable safety risk regarding non-discharge dismantling. In addition, non-discharge dismantling will inevitably result in increased damage to the equipment, and meanwhile, increase the risk of fire and explosion. The discharging process can be broadly categorized into two main types: chemical discharge and physical discharge. Chemical discharge mainly utilizes solutions like dilute sodium chloride or sodium sulfate to corrode the internal structure of LIBs, facilitating in power dissipation [23,24]. This approach is preferred for its simplicity, low cost, and high efficiency, and is widely employed by recycling enterprises. However, chemical discharge can result in an inevitable loss of valuable metals. As we calculated, the loss rates of Li-Ni-Co-Mn are observed to range from 0.1% to 0.25%. While this variation is not considered to be of significance, it cannot be disregarded. In addition, chemical discharge can result in the leakage of electrolytes, and the generation of toxic gaseous pollutants including hydrogen fluoride (HF), hydrocarbons, methoxymethane (DME), and DMC [25,26]. From the perspective of regular white-listed enterprises that have mandatory environmental protection requirements, the implementation of the chemical discharge method will result in increased investment in protection systems and equipment, thereby leading to a relative reduction in profitability. Physical discharge does not involve water and therefore will not produce wastewater, which is more eco-friendly than chemical discharge. Currently, there are three main types of physical discharge methods including energy-saving discharge, load discharge, and puncture discharge. Energy-saving discharge is the method using inverters to transform the direct current into alternating current and transmit the residual electrical energy of spent batteries into the power grid. This approach has the potential to facilitate the secondary utilization of battery power resources, which is widely regarded as the most eco-friendly method. However, the equipment requirements are comparatively high, thus necessitating a certain amount of initial investment. Load discharge is the method loading of both ends of LIBs with thermal loads to consume the residual electrical energy in the form of thermal energy, and the commonly used thermal loads include electronic loads, resistive loads, and conductive powder loads. Load discharge is particularly suited to achieving the rapid discharge of LIBs and is considered the most widely employed physical discharge method. However, this method poses a significant explosion risk due to the quick conversion of battery residual electrical energy to thermal energy, especially during large-scale discharging treatment, and thus requires close monitoring. Puncture discharge is the method of puncturing LIBs to make the battery short-circuited internally and rapidly reduce the voltage to zero through an internal violent reaction. It has the highest discharge efficiency but also the highest risk of fire and explosion, particularly with high residual voltage. Consequently, this method is frequently employed in conjunction with other discharging techniques and is well-suited for the discharge of LIBs that have reached their cut-off voltage. 3.1.2 Dismantling process The dismantling process can be divided into battery pack dismantling, module dismantling, and battery cell dismantling. Battery pack dismantling is the process of dismantling the connecting parts to obtain single modules. The order of dismantling is as follows: plastic casing, wiring harness, busbar, battery management system (BMS), and so on. Module dismantling is the process of obtaining individual battery cells, which requires the use of cutting equipment to separate the casing, metal busbar, and circuit board between the battery cells (Fig. 5 a). Battery cell dismantling is also known as “fine dismantling”, is the process to obtain the LIBs core or cathode materials by a flexible way. This process provides a solution to solving the “first mixed and then divided” problem inherent to the conventional recycling process. By preventing the metal shell from entering the crushing line, the impurity content in the positive and negative electrode active materials is significantly reduced, as is the sorting difficulty. When lithium carbonate (Li2CO3) prices exceeded RMB 600,000 per tonne in 2022, the “pyro-metallurgy + wet metallurgy” combined process was the best option. It improves Li extraction rates by sacrificing certain operating expenses, thus increasing corporate profits. However, as Li prices decline, this strategy becomes less viable. In the current low-price environment (<RMB 100,000 per tonne), controlling operating costs is of primary importance. Consequently, many companies have chosen the fine dismantling process instead. Using low-cost labor can significantly reduce operating costs in industrial production, thereby achieving positive profitability for comprehensive recycling enterprises. Therefore, despite the current limitations of fine dismantling technology, which still faces challenges in meeting the requirement of mechanical automation and continues to rely heavily on manual dismantling with low efficiency and elevated security risks [27], using low-cost labor for dismantling can offer more favorable economic benefits and is viable in the current downturn situation of Li price. 3.1.3 Testing process The testing process serves as the primary determinant of whether the spent automotive LIBs should be selected for reusing process or recycling process. According to the national standards, spent automotive LIBs with a real capacity between 40% and 80% should be designated for reusing, and less than 40% for recycling. The first step in testing spent automotive LIBs is to inspect their external appearance for signs of bulging, deformation, leakage, corrosion, or other visible damage to assess their reusability. Subsequently, an electrochemical measurement for the state of charge (SOC) and the state of health (SOH) of LIBs is conducted, which indicates the current battery voltage and battery real capacity, respectively. The SOC is commonly measured by the open circuit voltage method, mainly for the primary judgment of the battery performance. If a battery was measured as 0 V, it means it has been broken and cannot be reused. Otherwise, the SOH evaluation is conducted by cyclic charge and discharge method, for the further judgment of the battery performance and classification of LIBs. The LIBs that are tested as qualified can be re-packaged and reused as secondary reusing products [27]. 3.1.4 Reusing process The reusing process, or “echelon utilization”, is a degraded secondary utilization for spent automotive LIBs, by which the spent LIBs from a high-standard application scenario can be reused in another low-standard application scenario [27]. As illustrated in Fig. 5b, the spent automotive LIBs that are tested as qualified for echelon utilization, can be directly or indirectly reused for energy storage systems, backup power of communication equipment, energy storage devices of solar streetlights, low-speed electric vehicles, etc. Otherwise, they cannot be applied for echelon utilization, but treated by the recycling process. The detection and evaluation steps in testing process are very important for echelon utilization process, which decides the security and lifespan of reusing batteries. Generally, the cost of LIBs packs is considerable, accounting for 40% of the whole new energy vehicle, and the echelon utilization of spent automotive LIBs can increase business profits and reduce the operating pressure of the production line. Therefore, it is a high priority to consider the secondary use for spent automotive LIBs if they can meet the requisite reusing criteria, followed by the consideration of the recycling process. However, reused batteries have considerable security risks and high unobtrusiveness, so the service life and safety of restructured battery packs are of great concern. Consequently, compared to T-LIBs, LFPs are more appropriate for secondary use due to their low cost, slow capacity degradation, high cycle life, and satisfactory safety performance. On the contrary, T-LIBs are more suitable for recycling due to their rapid degradation and the presence of valuable Ni-Co-Li metals. 3.1.5 Crushing process The crushing process is usually the first step in recycling, used to crush battery cells with less than 40% capacity into fine materials, making them easier for subsequent pyrolysis and screening. This process is highly efficient, cost-effective, and suitable for large-scale industrial use. Consequently, despite challenges in ensuring material quality and meeting environmental standards, many small workshops frequently employ the “dismantling + multi-stage crushing + screening” process for pre-treatment. The most important reason for choosing this combined process is its potential for high returns with minimal investment, especially if environmental protection requirements are not considered. In general, a discharging pre-treatment is required before the crushing process to reduce the risk of short-circuiting and subsequent explosion. Recently, two alternative methods have been developed, which can allow the direct crushing of LIBs without preliminary discharging. The two methods are known as “charged crushing” technology and “cryogenic freezing crushing” technology. The former involves crushing directly in a vacuum or an inert atmosphere including nitrogen, argon and carbon dioxide, etc. This greatly reduces the risk of short-circuiting in the oxygen-deficient environment, making it a promising technology for potential application. This technology is highly praised by some recycling enterprises including LUEN MEI GROUP, RUICYCLE, JIANGYE NEW ENERGY, and GEP ECOTECH, and has been gradually adopted by some newly-built LIBs recycling projects. The latter involves reducing the reaction material to −200 °C, which effectively eliminates any reaction activity within the battery and can conduct crushing treatment directly without pre-discharging [28]. However, this technology has a high requirement for refrigeration equipment, thus resulting in significant initial investment. This technology originates from abroad and is currently utilized to a very limited extent in China due to the high costs. 3.1.6 Pyrolysis process The pyrolysis process is primarily used to eliminate the PVDF binder present in crushed material, thereby facilitating the separation of the electrode active material from the adhered metal shell. Meanwhile, pyrolysis can effectively release the Li from its crystalline structure through the collapse of the oxygen framework to form Li2CO3 [29]. The pyrolysis process is similar to conventional incineration but is conducted in an inert atmosphere. Consequently, pyrolysis is a highly referable and mature technology. It is often used in the “pyro-metallurgy and hydro-metallurgy” combined process to improve the leaching rate of valuable metals and the quality of resulting products. The pyro-metallurgy part usually uses conventional pyrolysis or alternative pyrometallurgical methods to enhance the leaching effect and metal recovery, while the hydro-metallurgy part focuses on leaching and separating different metals. The screening process includes both sieving and separation processes. The sieving process is frequently conducted in conjunction with the crushing process. The principal sieving equipment are vibrating sieves and drum sieves, which rely on the differing particle sizes of the materials to achieve their separation. In practical industrial production, the sieving process can be utilized with high-pressure airflow to achieve the black powder recovery from the pyrolysis materials. The separation process encompasses a multitude of techniques, including wind separation, magnetic separation, color separation, weight separation, flotation, cyclone separation, eddy current separation, and electrostatic separation, etc. The processes of wind selection, weight separation, and flotation are based on the density of the material difference in the way of material separation. Wind selection is achieved using a blower and can be used for the separation of lightweight plastics. Flotation and weight separation employ water as a medium for separation, and the key distinction between them is that the former requires the use of a flotation agent, whereas the latter can be used in the fluid medium for beneficiation. Magnetic separation is a process whereby the Fe, Co, Ni, and other magnetic metal components are separated through a strong magnetic field. Color separation is mainly based on the difference in optical properties of materials, by which materials of different colors are separated using photoelectric detection technology. Cyclone separation is mainly using a cyclone separator to achieve gas–solid separation. Eddy current separation and electrostatic separation are both based on the differing conductivity of materials to achieve the separation process. The distinction mainly lies in the manner of their operation. Eddy current separation utilizes the differing trajectories and paths of materials within an eddy current magnetic field, whereas electrostatic separation employs the differing trajectories and paths of materials within a high-voltage electric field. In addition, eddy current separation is applicable to materials with a particle size exceeding 5 mm, whereas electrostatic separation is applicable to materials with a particle size below 1 mm. 3.2 Pyro-metallurgy Pyro-metallurgy is defined as the process utilizing high-temperature thermochemical technology for the recovery of valuable metals. The principal techniques employed in this process include reduction smelting, reduction roasting, and salt-assisted roasting. 3.2.1 Reduction smelting As illustrated in Fig. 7 , reduction smelting is the process of converting valuable metals in LIBs into molten metal alloys by adding slagging agents including CaO, SiO2, MgO, Al2O3, and reducing agents like coke, Al, biomass, waste plastics at temperatures above 1,000 °C [32]. At 1475 °C, Ni, Co, and Cu are almost fully recovered as metal alloys, with recovery rates of 99.30%, 99.79%, and 99.30%, respectively [33]. Mn and Li are mainly found as oxides in the molten slag, accounting for 47.03% and 2.63%, respectively. By using 1.0 (w/w) sulfuric acid for leaching, the recovery rates of Li and Mn from the slag can reach 94.85% and 79.85%, respectively [33]. The reduction smelting process is relatively simple, offering a high recovery rate of valuable metals such as Co and Ni. Meanwhile, it is capable of continuous operation and large-scale production without pre-treatment, making it an excellent candidate for industrial application. However, this method has a significant limitation in that it fails to consider the recycling of Mn and Li metals [33]. Most Mn is in oxide form in the smelting slag, with only a small amount recovered as alloy form. Moreover, the loss of Li is considerable in such a high-temperature environment. Li is almost absent in metal alloys and only a tiny amount is in smelting slag. Most Li is emitted as exhaust gas away from the furnace. This is mainly due to lithium's high saturated vapor pressure and strong affinity for oxygen. At elevated temperatures during reduction smelting, Li continuously evaporates and enters the gas phase as oxides, ultimately becoming incorporated into the soot. Theoretically, secondary recovery of Li and Mn can be achieved through a further leaching process. However, in practical production, the smelting slag is often directly used as building materials without extraction. Moreover, the recovery of Li from soot is challenging due to its complex composition, resulting in the loss of valuable Li and Mn resources. 3.2.2 Reduction roasting Reduction roasting is a novel technology that has been developed based on reduction smelting, which solves the problem of serious loss of Li in reduction smelting. It allows for the prioritized extraction of Li by adding an external reducing agent, significantly improving the Li extraction rate. Reduction roasting can be readily achieved over 600 °C, significantly reducing energy consumption compared to reduction smelting. In the reduction roasting process, Ni, Co, and Mn are mainly converted into insoluble metal monomers or low-valent oxides, while Li is converted into soluble Li2CO3 or lithium oxide. This allows for easy separation of Li through a simple water-leaching process. Overall, reduction roasting technology is a significant advancement for the comprehensive recycling of spent automotive LIBs. It has changed the recycling concept of conventional hydro-metallurgy from post-lithium extraction to pre-lithium extraction, avoiding Li loss in intermediate extraction and separation processes, and greatly improving Li extraction rates. During high Li prices, the pre-lithium extraction process of reduction roasting offers significant economic benefits. In industrial production, it is challenging to achieve a Li recovery rate of 80% through conventional methods. However, the reduction roasting process can significantly improve this rate to about 85% [34]. It is estimated that each 1% increase in Li recovery rate will increase the operating revenue by about RMB 5 million for a spent automotive LIBs comprehensive recycling project with a 20,000-tonne annual capacity. Despite the current downturn in Li price, reduction roasting is also an important technology recognized by the recycling industry, with considerable market application potential. Reduction roasting can also effectively utilize low-price negative electrode materials to achieve comprehensive utilization of battery waste. The negative electrode of LIBs is primarily composed of graphite, which is a valuable reductive carbonaceous material. By utilizing the positive and negative electrode materials of LIBs, it is possible to achieve an in situ reduction roasting reaction without adding exogenous reductants, thus ensuring the successful recycling of resources and the protection of the environment. 3.2.3 Salt-assisted roasting The most salient issue associated with pyro-metallurgy is the considerable energy consumption and the relatively low recovery of Li. While reduction roasting can address certain issues, it is still not a perfect solution. The primary challenge with reduction roasting lies in the fact that the pre-lithium extraction technology is largely dependent on the water solubility of Li2CO3. However, due to the slightly soluble nature of Li2CO3 in water, the extraction process is incomplete, resulting in a low recovery rate. Additionally, the temperature required for carbothermal reduction is relatively high, and Li2CO3 will evaporate into the flue or slag over 800 °C, resulting in relatively high energy consumption and the loss of Li. Therefore, inspired by the reduction roasting technology, the salt-assisted roasting technology has been developed by some researchers. Compared to reduction roasting, salt-assisted roasting mainly relies on salt as the reaction core while carbon is the reaction core of reduction roasting [35]. The salt-assisted roasting has a higher Li recovery rate and is more economically viable with a lower carbon footprint than reduction roasting. Meanwhile, salt-assisted roasting is more flexible and can be applied to recycle all types of spent LIBs. As illustrated in Fig. 8 , salt-assisted roasting converts stable metal compounds into soluble metal salts by first adding exogenous roasting agents and subsequent mixed roasting of spent automotive LIBs cathode materials with these agents. Thereafter, the roasted products can be combined with water leaching, acid leaching, and other processes to achieve graded extraction of metals. Based on the roasting agent type, it can be categorized into sulfation, chlorination, and nitrification roasting. The sulfation roasting process mainly relies on the sulfur dioxide generated by the thermal decomposition of exogenously introduced sulfide. The reductive properties of +4 valence sulfur result in the reduction of high-valent metals present in the cathode materials of spent automotive LIBs to their low-valent counterparts [36]. This facilitates the generation of corresponding sulfate salts, thereby transforming the insoluble metal compounds into soluble sulfate salts (Eqs. (5)–(7)). The sulfation roasting can be conducted at temperatures between 200 and 600 °C, which is further reduced compared to that of reduction roasting. These soluble chlorine salts can then be separated based on their differing solubility in various extraction solvents. The most common chlorinating agent for chlorine roasting is ammonium chloride, which can efficiently extract valuable metals at temperatures below 400 °C. Consequently, selective extraction of Li can be achieved by a facile one-step water leaching separation. It has been demonstrated that the leaching rate of Li by nitrification roasting can reach 98%, which is 10% higher than that of direct nitric acid leaching (85%). Furthermore, the roasting temperature of nitrification roasting is only 250 °C, significantly reducing the energy consumption of the pyro-metallurgy process. Meanwhile, the nitrogen oxides produced can be converted into nitric acid and recycled using pressurized acid adsorption technology, avoiding secondary pollution and showing great market potential. However, the large amounts of NO x generated pose significant corrosion risks to the roasting equipment, requiring a considerable initial investment to ensure equipment performance. 3.3 Hydro-metallurgy The hydro-metallurgy process is an important method for leaching, separating, and purifying valuable metals from spent automotive LIBs. It involves leaching the batteries with acidic or alkaline solvents, followed by separation and purification through precipitation, extraction, and selective adsorption. The hydro-metallurgy process is a mature method for recycling valuable metals and is widely used in most comprehensive recycling enterprises for spent automotive LIBs in China. Despite the complexity and longer treatment period, the hydro-metallurgy process offers numerous significant advantages. These include low operating costs, suitability for room temperature and normal pressure, ease of control and operation, minimal equipment requirements, and high metal recovery and purity. Ultimately, these factors render it highly advantageous for recycling valuable metals [37]. Based on the leaching agent employed, hydro-metallurgy is mainly categorized into acid leaching and ammonia leaching methods. 3.3.1 Inorganic acid leaching The most commonly used acid-leaching agents in the hydro-metallurgy process are inorganic acids like sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, and phosphoric acid [37]. Among them, hydrochloric acid is the most effective acid-leaching agent due to its strong ability to destroy material surface layers with chloride ions. Under optimal conditions, it can achieve a leaching rate of 99% for Li, Ni, Co, Mn, and other valuable metals in cathode materials [38]. However, it produces a large amount of hydrogen chloride and chlorine gas, causing environmental concerns and limiting its use. Among all inorganic acid leaching systems, the sulfuric acid leaching system is the most prevalent, which offers numerous superior characteristics, including strong acidity, high leaching rate, high boiling point, and relatively low price. It has been demonstrated that the “sulfuric acid + hydrogen peroxide” combined leaching system can effectively leach LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 materials, achieving leaching rates of over 98.5% for Li, Ni, Co, Mn, and other valuable metals. Compared to sulfuric acid, inorganic acid leaching systems of nitric acid and phosphoric acid are less commonly recommended. Specifically, the nitric acid leaching system has considerable oxidative ability and can oxide the variable metals to higher valence states, thereby rendering the leaching process more challenging and reducing its effectiveness. Meanwhile, during nitric acid leaching, a large amount of nitric acid will be volatilized and toxic nitric oxide gas can be produced. As for the phosphoric acid leaching system, the critical deficiency is its insufficient acidity. To achieve the same leaching effect as sulfuric acid, the phosphoric acid concentration must be significantly increased or the solid–liquid ratio reduced. On the other hand, the phosphoric acid leaching system also has its unique advantage for selectively leaching LFP. This is mainly based on the principle that the dissolution rate of LFP is much higher than that of hydrogen evolution reaction rate from impurity Al. In a certain phosphoric acid leaching process, LFP is preferentially dissolved into the liquid phase, releasing Li and Fe ions, while Al foil remains in the solid phase. This method can achieve a leaching rate of LFP over 93% and Al less than 20% [39]. Furthermore, combining phosphoric acid with hydrogen peroxide can selectively leach Li from LFP at a rate of 97.57% [40]. 3.3.2 Organic acid leaching After leaching, the precipitation and purification processes are usually required to remove impurities like Fe, Al, and Cu from the solution. The inorganic acid leaching process usually utilizes substantial quantities of acid, thereby requiring considerable amounts of additional alkali to neutralize it before precipitation [41]. Moreover, it also produces large amounts of acidic wastewater and toxic gases like chlorine, sulfur trioxide, and NO x [42]. These must be carefully treated to avoid secondary pollution, thus increasing the disposal costs. Recently, researchers have tried using organic acids instead of inorganic acids for leaching. Organic acids have a superior capacity to achieve a comparable leaching rate to that of inorganic acids. Meanwhile, it has excellent environmental protection properties including high biodegradability, high recycling value, and low ecological toxicity. The most commonly used organic acids include citric acid, oxalic acid, and malic acid [43]. Citric acid is non-volatile, non-corrosive, non-damaging, non-decomposable, and non-oxidizing [42]. It also will not produce toxic gases during leaching. For instance, the leaching of Li-Ni-Co-Mn by citric acid under optimal conditions can reach 99%, 97%, 95%, and 94%, respectively [44]. Moreover, the citric acid leaching system can be also employed for the selective leaching of LFP (Eqs. (12)–(14)). Compared to phosphoric acid, the “citric acid + hydrogen peroxide” combined leaching system can facilitate preferential leaching of Al while retaining Fe in the solid phase as ferric phosphate. After 90 min, the leaching rate of Al and Fe is found to be 47.24% and 4.05%, respectively [45]. Despite disparate leaching effects of two components, the selective Al removal effect remains unsatisfactory. Therefore, the application of citric acid is confined to be used in selective leaching of LFP cathode materials with low Al impurity. Thirdly, organic acid leaching is too slow and prone to side reactions when dealing with materials with many impurities. Overall, these challenges make it difficult to apply organic acid leaching on a large scale for recycling spent automotive LIBs. 3.3.3 Ammonia leaching The leaching of spent automotive LIBs cathode materials frequently leads to various metal impurities, posing a major challenge for subsequent separation and purification processes. To improve the efficiency and simplify the process, the superiority of selective leaching is becoming more and more prominent. Ammonia leaching technology has received considerable attention due to its capacity to selectively leach valuable metals and separate lower-value metals. This method works based on the differing complexing ability of ammonia (NH3) with different metals. It has strong complexing ability with valuable metals including Li, Ni, and Co, and can form stable metal-ammonia complexes at lower temperatures. Meanwhile, it has a weak complexing ability with low-value metals like Mn, Fe, and Al [50]. Therefore, ammonia leaching is considered an effective method for selectively leaching and separating impurities from valuable metals in spent automotive LIBs. The ammonia leaching system frequently employs ammonia as the leaching agent, ammonium salt as the buffer, and hydrogen peroxide and sulfite as the reducing agent [49]. For example, a mixed leaching system using ammonia, ammonium bicarbonate, and ammonium sulfite can achieve almost 100% leaching of Ni and Cu under the best conditions. In addition, Co and Li are leached at 80.99% and 60.53% respectively, while the leaching rate of Al is nearly 0, indicating a selective leaching effect [51]. However, the use of sulfite results in the production of sulfate wastewater, thereby increasing the associated treatment costs. Moreover, the leaching effect of Co and Li in this system is less desirable. Therefore, hydrogen peroxide is employed as the reducing agent in place of sulfite, and the leaching system of “ammonia-ammonium bicarbonate-hydrogen peroxide” is implemented. In this system, ammonia serves as the leaching agent, ammonium bicarbonate acts as the buffering agent, and hydrogen peroxide is utilized as the reducing agent. This approach has the potential to enhance the leaching rate of Li, Ni, and Co to 81.2%, 96.4%, and 96.3%, respectively [52]. Meanwhile, the leaching of Mn and Al is effectively avoided. As a result, process adjustment significantly improves ammonia leaching efficiency and avoids sulfate wastewater issues. The ammonia leaching technology exhibits selective leaching properties, and process ammonia can be evaporated and recycled with minimal environmental impact. However, the separation of Li, Ni, and Co remains challenging. Therefore, to fully utilize the selectivity of ammonia leaching technology, it should be employed in conjunction with other effective metallurgy processes. 3.4 Microbial metallurgy Microbial metallurgy is the method that primarily relies on the metabolic secretions of specific microorganisms to facilitate the reaction with valuable metals, converting them into soluble metal ions (Fig. 9 ). Under optimal leaching conditions, the leaching rates of Li and Co metals can exceed 95% and 90%, respectively [55]. The primary reaction mechanisms are as follows [56]. Specifically, LIBs are first leached or extracted to obtain a composite salt solution. Subsequently, a purification process is conducted, whereby electrochemical deposition is carried out by applying direct current (DC) voltage to both ends of the solution. Those with low reduction potentials are preferentially reduced and precipitated on the cathode. By adjusting the reduction potentials of electrodes, it is possible to achieve the separation of valuable metals. Moreover, the electrochemical deposition method can be utilized to remove the impurities in the leaching solution. For instance, in the case of a Cu-Fe-Al-Ni-Co-Mn-Li composite solution, the first purification stage is removing Fe and Al impurities through a chemical precipitation process. The second purification stage is removing Cu impurities through an electrochemical deposition process. The process primarily relies on the fact that the standard electrode potential of Cu is greater than 0, whereas that of Ni, Co, Mn, and Li ions is less than 0. This leads to the reductive precipitation of Cu ions on the cathode. Consequently, the removal of Cu impurity can reach 99.11%, with the final loss of Ni, Co, and Mn only being 0.42%, 0.25%, and 0.39%, respectively [61]. Electrochemical deposition is a highly selective method for metal separation, offering advantages including simple operation, high environmental values, and the absence of the need for exogenous reagents, which avoids the introduction of impurities, and the purity of produced metal can exceed 99% [62]. However, this method is not applicable to the leaching solutions with complex compositions. The potential of Li is relatively low, and water will be preferred for electrolysis before Li. Therefore, Li cannot be electrodeposited in solution. Moreover, the potential of Co and Ni is in proximity, making it susceptible to co-deposition if electrolyzed directly. Generally, it is recommended to combine electrochemical deposition with hydrometallurgy for complex solutions. This is primarily because electrochemical deposition is used to separate valuable metals from the leaching solution produced by hydro-metallurgy process. However, this will increase the process complexity and raise extraction costs. Recently, a novel electrochemical deposition method has been developed, which can be used individually to recover Li-Ni-Co-Mn metals as Li2CO3, Ni-Co alloy, and MnO2 with recovery rates of 85.5%, 99.40%, 91.00%, 90.68%, respectively [63]. This method employed dimension stable anode inert alloy as the anode, Cu plate as the cathode, CuSO4 solution as the electrolyte, and the electrochemical deposition process is divided into two steps. The first step is conducted by the electrolysis of CuSO4 electrolyte to produce sulfuric acid to leach the valuable metals from spent LIBs. The second step is conducted by electrochemical deposition of leaching metals. This method provides a promising approach to recover valuable metals in spent LIBs individually. However, it still has the co-deposition problem, and the reaction time is too long, indicating more operation costs. In conclusion, the present electrochemical deposition method is still restricted for practical industrial production due to its high energy consumption, limited processing scale, and complex process, which needs further research and industrial practice, particularly for controlling process costs and increasing the electrochemical deposition efficiency. 3.7 Direct regeneration Direct regeneration, also called direct remediation, is a novel green recycling technology that has emerged in recent years, which is a non-destructive repair technology [64]. It is found that Li deficiency is the primary cause of capacity degradation and irreversible structural changes in LIBs. The direct regeneration process targets the root cause of capacity degradation in LIBs. It can restore the electrochemical performance of cathode materials to its maximum extent by replenishing missing metal components and repairing structural defects. As shown in Fig. 10 , direct regeneration methods mainly consist of solid-phase sintering, solvent thermal regeneration, eutectic molten salt, and electrochemical restoration [65]. 3.7.1 Solid-phase sintering Solid-phase sintering is the most conventional and widely used method. The high-temperature calcination of spent automotive LIBs cathode material with Li replenishment agents can restore missing Li elements and the crystal structure (Fig. 10a). The first step of solid-phase sintering involves detaching the cathode material from Al foil, and then using high-temperature calcination to eliminate the binder and carbon powder. The second step involves determining the elemental composition of calcined cathode material through wet digestion, followed by adjusting the elemental composition with missing metal salts. The third step involves recalcining the adjusted mixture to obtain the regenerated cathode material. The solid-phase sintering process offers numerous advantages, including low cost, low energy consumption, simple operation, no emissions of wastewater and waste gas, and no requirements for acid and alkali leaching, which makes it an extremely efficient method for the ecological closed-loop application of spent automotive LIBs. However, the regenerated cathode materials have shorter cycle life and lower capacity, and it is challenging to reach their original electrochemical performance, usually only suitable for downgrading applications. Furthermore, this method is not applicable to battery materials containing a significant number of impurities and severe lattice damage. Meanwhile, the amount of Li deficiency in the material must be precisely determined. However, since spent automotive LIBs originate from a multitude of sources, the degree of Li deficiency often varies considerably. In the event of large-scale regeneration, the accurate determination of the average amount of Li deficiency in the material remains a significant challenge, and related issues require further investigation. 3.7.2 Solvent thermal regeneration The solvent thermal regeneration method can be broadly classified into two main categories of hydrothermal method and ionic liquid method. Besides solid-phase sintering, the hydrothermal method is another widely employed technology for regenerating spent automotive LIBs cathode materials [70]. This method employs water as the reaction solvent, whereby spent cathode materials are immersed in the solution containing Li source, and then the hydrothermal reaction is performed under subcritical conditions. The hydrothermal process regenerates spent cathode materials through “dissolution and recrystallization”. As illustrated in Fig. 10b, hydrothermal regeneration uses lithium sulfate (Li2SO4‧H2O) as the Li source and lithium sulfite (Na2SO3) as the reducing agent. The regenerated material presents remarkable electrochemical performance, retaining a capacity of over 98.6% even after 300 cycles [71]. Compared to solid-phase sintering, the hydrothermal method exhibits superiority of low reaction temperature, short reaction time, great metal diffusion, and excellent material dispersion. However, it requires higher reaction pressure, demanding more advanced hydrothermal equipment. Similar to the hydrothermal method, ionic liquid regeneration is the method of replacing the reaction medium of water with ionic liquid for regeneration. Generally, ionic liquid is composed of anions and cations and appears liquid state at room temperature. It exhibits strong thermal stability, non-volatility, and strong selective solubility. Compared to hydrothermal method, ionic liquid method has milder reaction requests, stronger ion transport ability, and can be conducted under low temperature and low-pressure conditions [72]. However, ionic liquids are comparatively expensive, toxic and pose safety risks during operation, which diminishes the perceived advantages compared to hydrothermal methods. Furthermore, ionic liquid and hydrothermal methods are both Li replenishment repair processes, which are only applicable to material deactivation caused by Li deficiency [73]. It is important to recognize that not all decommissioning of cathode materials is caused by the loss of Li ions alone. Besides this, other factors such as phase change and structural collapse must also be considered. In the case of these materials, the application of solvent heat treatment alone is insufficient to achieve the desired effect. To regenerate cathode materials with excellent electrochemical performance, it is commonly necessary to combine with a high-temperature annealing process following solvent heat reaction, to achieve structural recovery. 3.7.3 Eutectic molten salt The conventional solid-phase sintering method can be described as a solid–solid contact reaction system. Despite the high degree of material mixing, ion diffusion of the solid-phase sintering method remains challenging. This ultimately leads to incomplete repair and imperfect performance of regenerated LIBs. On the other hand, the solvent heat regeneration method requires a second calcination and annealing treatment. Consequently, the eutectic molten salt method has been developed based on the above two methods. The eutectic molten salt method primarily utilizes high-temperature molten salt media to achieve Li replenishment and structural repair of spent cathode materials, thereby acquiring regenerated cathode materials with superior electrochemical performance (Fig. 10c). The key point of the eutectic molten salt method is replacing the Li replenishment agent from a single Li salt to a homogeneous system of Li-containing molten salts (e.g., LiOH-LiNO3 and KCl-KNO3-LiNO3, etc.). The mixed molten salt has a lower melting point than any single Li salt, and it can be converted to a liquid state at a lower temperature under high-temperature conditions than solid-phase sintering. When high-temperature molten salt is transformed into ionic liquid, the solid–solid reaction system is transformed into a solid–liquid reaction system. This results in an increase in the diffusion capacity of Li ions and the repair efficiency of the material. In particular, the liquid molten salt exists outside the spent cathode material in a parcel state, subsequently penetrating cathode particles through the microcracks and micropores on the surface. The higher concentration of Li ions in molten salt than that of cathode particles allows for the migration and diffusion of external Li ions into the cathode particles, where they react with the cathode particles to achieve the replenishment of Li. It is notable that cathode materials repaired by high-temperature molten salt have no need for second calcination. The eutectic molten salt method has been demonstrated to be an effective approach for the regeneration of spent cathode materials. The regenerated cathode materials exhibit a relatively intact layer structure, stable electrochemical performance, and good application potential. However, the method is associated with some significant drawbacks such as high consumption of Li salt and considerable cost. Consequently, recycling Li salt may be a crucial area of future research within this technology. Moreover, the above-mentioned direct regeneration methods including solid-phase sintering, solvent thermal, and eutectic molten salt methods are all dependent on heating or high-pressure conditions, largely restricting the practical industrial implementation of the direct regeneration process. Therefore, direct regeneration at ambient conditions can be one of the important directions for future research [74]. 3.7.4 Electrochemical remediation As shown in Fig. 10d, electrochemical remediation is a Li replenishment technique that mainly relies on charging and discharging reactions [75]. This process is suitable for the regeneration of LFPs. During the charging process, Fe(II) is oxidized to Fe(III), while Li is detached from LFP and migrates towards the negative electrode, and the discharging process is reversed (Eqs. (26) and (27). Spent automotive LIBs are subjected to a preliminary treatment to obtain positive electrode sheets. Subsequently, the electrode sheets are immersed in dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) in succession to eliminate the electrolyte and binder. Meanwhile, the spent cathode powder is subjected to a washing and drying process, resulting in the formation of Li x FePO4/C powder. Ultimately, the Li x FePO4/C powder is combined with the conductive agent and binder in a proportionate quantity of NMP and then coated onto the Al foil to re-form the battery-positive electrode sheet. The positive electrode sheet to be repaired is employed as the positive electrode, and the Li metal sheet is utilized as the negative electrode. The two components are assembled as a half-cell and subjected to three cycles of charge and discharge within a voltage range of 2.0–4.2 V. The electrochemical remediation of the positive electrode is deemed complete upon the third discharge, which is terminated at 2.0 V. In summary, the electrochemical remediation method does not necessitate the utilization of acid and alkali reagents, therefore resulting in minimal secondary pollution. However, it requires LIBs to be dismantled repeatedly during repair, which is a time-consuming process. Moreover, it is not suitable for cathode materials with extensive structural damage. The direct synthesis mainly includes co-precipitation, sol–gel and spray pyrolysis methods. 3.8.1 Co-precipitation The co-precipitation method involves initially co-precipitating metal ions from the leaching solution, followed by calcining the precursors to produce the regenerated cathode materials. The whole production process associated with co-precipitation is illustrated in Fig. 11 . Firstly, the waste cathode materials obtained by pre-treatment are leached to obtain a composite solution containing Li, Ni, Co, and Mn. Impurity ions in the solution are then removed by precipitation and extraction. Secondly, a certain amount of metal salts is added to make up for the lack of metal components in the solution. Thirdly, the precursors of cathode materials are obtained by adding precipitating agents like hydroxide, carbonate, oxalate, and others for co-precipitation. Finally, the precursors are regenerated with Li salts using a high-temperature solid-phase sintering method to form new regenerated cathode materials. The co-precipitation method can control the particle size distribution of the product by modifying the precipitation conditions. Furthermore, throughout the entire production process, the wastewater generated from the washing and filtration stages can be effectively recycled, thereby significantly mitigating the environmental impact. It is the preferred approach for preparing precursors, but it can lead to the co-precipitation of impurity ions, which may impair the electrochemical performance of the products. 3.8.2 Sol-gel The sol–gel method employs the organic acid as the both leaching agent and chelating agent. This is achieved through a series of processes, including leaching, hydrolysis, polymerization, and thermal evaporation, which are carried out in sequence to obtain a gel [77]. Subsequently, the gel is subjected to calcination, whereby the desired cathode materials are produced. The specific operational steps are illustrated in Fig. 12 . Firstly, the waste cathode materials obtained by pre-treatment are leached with the use of citric acid, malic acid, and other organic acids. Secondly, the proportion of metals in the leaching solution is adjusted by the addition of acetate or nitrate corresponding to Li, Ni, Co, and Mn, with the pH of the solution being adjusted by adding ammonia. Thirdly, the solution is subjected to constant stirring and heating to obtain a gel with a three-dimensional network structure. Finally, the regenerated cathode materials can then be obtained by the removal of organic components in the gel through high-temperature calcination. The products obtained by the sol–gel method exhibit excellent uniformity of particle size and high purity. However, this method is not well-suited to large-scale industrial production due to its complex operation, prolonged reaction time, high demand for reaction equipment, and considerable consumption of organic solvents [78]. 3.8.3 Spray pyrolysis Recently, a novel direct synthesis method, spray pyrolysis, has been developed by some researchers as shown in Fig. 13 . The method mainly comprises four steps including acid leaching, metal adjustment, ultrasonic atomization, and spray pyrolysis. The regenerated cathode materials present excellent electrochemical stability with a capacity of 81.7% after 300 cycles. Compared to the conventional co-precipitation and sol–gel techniques, this method offers a highly efficient approach to obtaining regenerated cathode materials by merging the precursor formation and calcination processes into one spray pyrolysis process. Consequently, the regenerated cathode material can be obtained in a single step through spray pyrolysis following the addition of external metal complements, resulting in a significant enhancement in the efficiency of the regeneration process. Spray pyrolysis sounds fantastic for recycling LIBs, but its industrial potential remains unclear and deserves further investigation. 4 Comprehensive recycling strategies and recommendations for spent automotive LIBs Before deciding to engage in the spent automotive LIBs recycling industry, a decisive premise cannot be ignored, which is far more important than any technical and technological demand. The most decisive point is whether the enterprise itself can obtain sufficient and sustainable resources for spent automotive LIBs. Without this, any claims are merely theoretical. 4.1 Comprehensive recycling strategies and recommendations for T-LIBs The T-LIBs contain many valuable metals, including Ni, Co, Li, and Mn, which contribute to their high recycling value. Meanwhile, reusing of secondary products derived from T-LIBs presents considerable security risks. Therefore, T-LIBs are more favorable to the recycling route. Currently, the valuable metal recovery process of T-LIBs mainly employs conventional hydro-metallurgy technology. This is because it is a well-designed technology with relatively low processing costs, high metal extraction rate, and purity. The pre-treatment process of hydro-metallurgy technology needs to be based on the market price of Li and the scale of the recycling line. Specifically, if Li price exceeds the break-even point of the pyrolysis process, it may be advisable to consider the combined process of pyro-metallurgy and hydro-metallurgy techniques, i.e., “charged crushing + pyrolysis calcination + hydro-metallurgy”. This combined process can achieve a high metal extraction rate and purity and is suitable for industrial large-scale production. However, the comprehensive cost is considerable, thus requiring comprehensive economic assessment. If calculated profitable, this combined process can largely amplify the corporate profits and create sustainable cash flow by expanding the production scale. In the event of a long-term decline in Li prices, enterprises must utilize cost-effective processes to ensure the viability of operations. In such circumstances, the high-temperature pyro-metallurgy process is not a viable option. A great alternative approach is the utilization of the conventional manual dismantling method, whereby a comparatively inexpensive labor force can be employed to produce higher-value battery cathode materials. The subsequent process is primarily determined by three factors: construction scale, production route, and comprehensive strength of recycling enterprises. If enterprises consider further improving the extraction rate and purity of valuable metals to amplify the profitability, low-temperature reduction roasting and low-temperature salt-assisted roasting may be employed as a means of further pre-treatment prior to hydro-metallurgy. Alternatively, the process may be directly integrated into the subsequent hydrometallurgical operations. If budgetary constraints exist, direct recycling of LIBs only by pre-treatment to sell battery cores and cathode materials is a practical choice. Another crucial aspect of the comprehensive recycling industry of spent automotive LIBs is the timing of entry. Ni, Co, Li, and other valuable metals are cyclical products with cyclical price fluctuations. Therefore, it is essential for enterprises engaged in the recycling of such materials to maintain a close observation of market developments to cultivate an acute sense of market perception, and to be able to make timely judgments regarding future trends. To mitigate the impact of Li price fluctuations on corporate production, it is recommended that enterprises establish a large storage system of their own. This will enable them to adopt the strategy of selling products during periods of peak Li prices and purchasing stocks during periods of downturn, thereby simultaneously maximizing benefits and minimizing risks. 4.2 Comprehensive recycling strategies and recommendations for LFPs LFPs are composed of only one single valuable metal, namely Li. Consequently, the recycling value of LFPs is relatively low. However, the high security and long lifespan of LFPs make them a preferred option for secondary reusing. Therefore, it is recommended that the reusing route be adopted instead of the recycling route for LFPs unless their reusing values are no longer applicable. Regarding the recycling route of LFPs, it is not feasible to adopt the similar process as used for T-LIBs. Firstly, LFPs have relatively low recycling values. Secondly, the Li loss by conventional pyro-metallurgy process is significant. Thirdly, conventional hydro-metallurgy is a complex process that relies heavily on strong acids and alkalis, which will generate considerable amounts of wastewater. Moreover, conventional hydro-metallurgy is a total dissolution process, whereby low-value Fe is subjected to the “firstly dissolved and then precipitated” process, which significantly increases the pressure and operating cost on the production line. Particularly for the current downturn in Li price, conventional hydro-metallurgy is an economically unviable and environmentally unsustainable option. Instead, there are two alternative processes for the comprehensive recycling of LFPs. The first is the selective extraction of Li. This process primarily relies on the stability of the olivine structure of LFP, which is not readily destroyed. The oxidation of LFP Fe(II) to Fe(III) results in the conversion of LFP into FePO4. Li ions can be de-embedded from the cathode to achieve selective Li extraction, with an extraction rate of up to 99%. In practical action, a combined process of “phosphoric acid + hydrogen peroxide” and “mechanical chemistry” process is recommended. The second is the direct regeneration of LFP. The capacity degradation of LFPs is primarily attributed to the loss of active Li, rather than structural attenuation or the deactivation of active materials. The replenishment of Li can effectively restore the electrochemical performance of LFPs [81]. When initial investment is adequate, the hydrothermal regeneration method is currently the most suitable technology for LFPs, as it is cost-effective, has a great regeneration effect, and can be better adapted to industrial large-scale production. 5 Conclusions A variety of recycling technologies are available for recycling spent automotive LIBs, as summarized in Table 5 . The present study provides an overview of the characteristics, technical advantages and disadvantages, and potential applications of recycling processes. Comprehensive recycling strategies and recommendations are proposed based on different spent automotive LIBs. Investors and industry practitioners should consider several factors when selecting the appropriate process to construct a spent automotive LIBs recycling line. These factors include resource advantages, economic capacities, existing conditions, and other aspects. Once the recycling process has been determined, detailed calculations should be conducted to ascertain the break-even point and return on investment. Meanwhile, it is essential to monitor market conditions closely to identify optimal purchasing and selling opportunities, thereby mitigating the potential risks associated with price fluctuations and their impact on enterprise production. coredata.dc:description: The recycling of spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) has aroused considerable interest among the general public, industry professionals, and academic researchers, driven by its environmental, resource recovery, and economic benefits, particularly for those used in new energy vehicles. However, recycling spent automotive LIBs for industrial production remains challenging due to technical feasibility, recycling efficiency, economic viability, and environmental sustainability. This review aims to systematically analyze the status of spent automotive LIBs recycling, and provide an overall review of the full-chain recycling processes for technical evaluation and selection. Firstly, it carefully describes the pre-treatment process, which includes discharging, disassembly, inspection, crushing, pyrolysis, and sieving of LIBs. Subsequently, it examines the principal technologies in extracting valuable metals, including pyro-metallurgy, hydro-metallurgy, microbial metallurgy, mechanical chemistry, and electrochemical deposition. A comprehensive analysis of the operation, mechanism, efficiency, and economics is provided, helping readers understand the technical advantages, disadvantages, and applicable scenarios of each process. Furthermore, it also considers novel environmentally-friendly processes, such as direct regeneration and direct synthesis, and analyzes their potential and limitations in the resource recycling field. Finally, differentiated comprehensive recycling strategies are proposed for typical spent automotive LIBs, aiming at providing effective guidance and recommendations for industrial investors and practitioners, and promoting sustainable development of the comprehensive recycling industry.
